entry.title: Notes for 'Process Management Modules in Perl' posted.

div.p: Brett covers some process management in Perl, including MCE and Parallel::ForkManager::Segmented.

entry.title: Notes for 'A /usr/bin/sendmail like perl script that uses SendGrid email delivery service' posted.

div.p: Julian Brown will describe a Perl script he wrote that uses SendGrid to handle outgoing server email. He'll cover the process, the script, and some DNS configuration.

entry.title: Notes for '2001: How our Grandfathers wrote OO Perl' posted.

div.p: Brett Estrade will tour the book Object Oriented Perl: A Comprehensive Guide to Concepts and Programming Techniques by Damien Conway. The book shows the old approach to OO in Perl.

entry.title: Notes for 'Perl 7: An Opinionated Introduction' posted.

div.p: James Keenan gives an introduction to the upcoming Perl 7 release. This is a chance to continue evolving Perl into the future, while providing a point to disconnect from some legacy behavior.

entry.title: Notes for 'Update on TPCiC and Perl 7, plus discussion' posted.

div.p: For this month's remote meeting, Todd Rinaldo will give a summary of where Perl stands today. We'll go on from there to a more general discussion among the teams.

entry.title: Notes for 'June Remote Social Meeting' posted.

div.p: A group of us hang out on Zoom and talk about whatever comes to mind.

entry.title: Notes for 'A TDD approach to learning' posted.

div.p: We'll hear from Evan Carroll about a project he's working on, and any other subjects we think to discuss.
Julian Brown covers the basics of SQL in this fundamentals talk.

entry.title: Notes for 'Perl Data Structures: Tips, Tricks, and Traps' posted.

div.p: Making the best use of Perl includes understanding and using its data structures. G. Wade Johnson will present the major Perl data structures, dipping slightly into implementation, but focusing mostly on the effective use of those structures.

entry.title: Notes for 'Coverage guided fuzzing the Perl interpreter' posted.

div.p: John Lightsey will present an early version of a talk he has scheduled for The Perl and Raku Conference this year. The talk will cover using fuzzing in analysis of the Perl interpreter. If you have interest in security, Perl, or fuzz testing, this will be the talk for you.

Except in the case of simple standalone scripts, Perl applications usually consist of multiple modules and the perl executable. In this discussion, we want to cover some of the ways you can deploy a Perl application to any environment.
Debbie presents a short introduction to how Core.org teaches kids of any age to think about programming.

entry.title: Notes for 'Constants: What They Provide and How to Mock Them' posted.

div.p: Evan Carroll will cover another aspect of testing in Perl by mocking constants.
Evan Carroll covers some of the reasons for using an Object Oriented paradigm when programming. He shows how Perl and a few other languages implement the appropriate concepts.

entry.title: Notes for 'Panel Discussion on Object Oriented Programming' posted.

div.p: Instead of a presentation, this is more of a question and answer session about Object Oriented Programming.

entry.title: Notes for 'Basic Unit Testing Concepts in Perl' posted.

div.p: Wade starts with some unit testing basics, introduces some of the Perl unit test frameworks, and then focuses on concepts and tricks to help you get more from your unit tests. While not attempting to cover the whole subject of unit testing, there should be something here for most.

entry.title: Notes for 'Test::Spec, Test Using a Declarative Testing Framework' posted.

div.p: Julian Brown describes his experiences with the Test::Spec unit testing framework.

entry.title: Notes for 'Julian in the Land of NoSQL' posted.

div.p: Julian Brown will be exploring the usage of the Arangodb NoSQL database as used a website he's working on.

entry.title: Notes for 'Getting Started With OpenShift - Using Containers for SysOps and Engineering' posted.

div.p: Robert Stone will do a demo of OpenShift, showing some of the high points of functionality.
